author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Long Post alert, but touches on a few things we harp on around here. 

So my little bro is in town- we made dinner for one of his oldest friends who just moved to town with his wife. He’s a fantastic mandolin player and his wife is a singer/songwriter. 

Of course I did the ol’ studio walk through, listening to all the tunes on the ear calibration playlist, then let them play some of their own favs. Of course they’re blown away and have never heard music like this etc. 

But to drive the point home I show them a song @Rollmottle and I turned around in just over 24 hours. “The reason for the speakers & treatment etc is so we can make decisions quickly blah blah blah.”  I pull up the session and we listen through and they’re loving it- but I’m noticing it doesn’t have the 3D thing that all the other music we’ve been listening to has. 

Then I show them the mastered version. An mp3. It’s louder and better sounding and all, until the first BGV stack hits… then it’s IMMERSIVE. We listened to the whole thing again just to enjoy the magic and notice all the ways the master improved it. So far beyond zapping resonances and making it loud, @Rollmottle made it sound… important. Made *me* sound like a good mixer. 

It was heavier lifting for him cause I didn’t have the benefit of time for fresh ears or to detail the vocal the way I normally would. Also had the good fortune of having @Ross Fortune on speed dial and on GMT to give it a listen at 5am PST. 

I’d you’re curious, or dubious, I’ll DM files so you can hear what I’m talking about. 

TL;DR: monitoring matters, fresh perspective matters. Don’t produce mix *and* master your own shit.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Re; Brauer workshop

-First 2 days were nothing technical, the 1st conversation he brought up was about TM and how meditation in general has helped him.
-Everything is feel-based, most technical Q's for the first 2 and a half days got the same reply: "It doesn't matter to me, i don't care what the thing is long as it feels good". 
-MHB actually seems to leave the planet while he's mixing, it's wild how immediate he gets into that space. Seemed to go way past "i love mixing and here's all the reasons i'm the shit" and it was inspiring to see the ego leave the equation. His decades of experience are playing directly into his ability to access the story of the song and present it in a compelling, live-feeling way. He mixes from inside the song and performs. Well, he does discovery, then shapes the sounds, then performs just about everything on faders.
-The biggest wake up call to me is that a lot of moves i've made on mixes did not have a good reason behind them. So continuing to ask "why" as I work is gonna be important, because I have to start catching myself and adjusting when the answer to "why" is "because someone said this preset is cool" or "because this is what I do to a vocal/guitar/drums". I feel music very deeply, it's why i got into this, but I feel like i've been poisoned against trusting that instinct and convinced that what we do is a technical job. I'm done being an observer of the art, i want to be bold.
-It's critical to build trust with clients right away, you can't assume anything in what they understand about how you feel. Telling them you love the song and you're excited to mix it is important, and never blaming production/artist/anything else for the mix being less than what it should be. never okay to say "i did my best", because that gives you an out and implies somebody else could do it better
-Therefore, you must believe when you sit down to mix that nobody is gonna interpret this song better than you.
-Generally i'm skeptical to just take on someone else's "method" and start operating in that space just becuase of the success they've had with it. Putting this week into practice is going to mean using his template to get reps in, listening and feeling and interacting in a new way and letting my brain "level up", if you will, then zooming out and making it my own.


I can distill this more and want to share about a couple other specifics, but I just realized I grabbed someone else's notebook by mistake when I left on the last day so I'll need to have them mail mine back to me.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Because I'm a huge Penn Jillette fan, I'll quote it from one of his books (which he has paraphrased many other times in essays and on podcasts):

"The big secret of magic is we are willing to work harder to accomplish something stupid than you can imagine. We'll practice things for years that you wouldn't consider investing an hour in. You can imagine spending half of your life under a bridge learning to play sax like Sonny Rollins, but you can't imagine spending five minutes learning to drop a palmed cell phone into a little pocket behind a cardboard cut out of Chris Angel while hanging across around its neck and talking a mile a minute without the slightest pause. I had to practice that a lot. A lot more than you can imagine. I had to practice it a lot more than you think it's worth. Our big secret is that it's worth more to us to do our tricks then you can even imagine. Our deep secret is simply misplaced priorities."

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Hey folks, back from mix with the masters with Jon & Teezio. I wanted to share just a little bit in case anyone else here is considering attending a workshop in the future. I was initially on the fence, but am very glad I went. 

Jon & Teezio were amazing together. I don't know how often MWTM does workshops with two engineers, but it really enriched the experience for me. It was actually comical how different their perspectives were on mixing, the business side, motivation for the work, lifestyle, etc... This created fascinating debate / conversation in the group. The Grammy nominations were announced while we were all together and we got to celebrate Jon & Teezio as a group for their I think combined 6 or 7 nominations. They brought in a bucket of champaign. All this after having gone through the sessions for said grammy nominated work earlier in the week. 10 / 10.

Rue Boyer studios is actually insane. Probably the best room I've been in.

There were attendees from all over the world. We ended up sharing mixes and receiving feedback from J&T. Hearing and sharing records in the same room with the people who made them with context provided from varying countries, cultures, genres, and scenes was as enlightening a music listening experience as I'm likely to have for the rest of my life.

So if anyone else here is on the fence in the future. Here's a tiny nudge.

author: cian riordan
content:
Outside of the studio? This totally changed me. Seeing things through… start to finish. Caring about every step of the process. We’ve done so many home DIY projects… I’d be up late the night before planning, up early double checking. Staying afterward to make sure everything to put away and cleaned up. I care. Invaluable in building a home studio. I enjoy the results every day, even 5 years later I get a grin when I walk into that room.

Learning to cook pizza? Figure out where you want be. I started doing this 2 years ago. I had no idea what I was doing. But I limited my variables, took things one step at a time. What kind of flour is best? Buy different ones. Try them. What hydration dough? Fuck if I know. Start with 60%… work up from there. How long to ferment? Etc Etc. I obsess over every step of this process. 

When I’m interested in something, I care about it. Nobody else has to, but I do. And I’ll go to bed at night, I’ll know that I’ve done the work to really know that it’s as good as it can be.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Now imagine you keep going, slowly improving but over time you start paying more and more attention to your hands and not to the shadows they cast. You become enchanted with the clever contortions of your fingertips but stop really connecting with their effect in the world

This is what obsession with sound and tones can become. Mistaking the sounds we use to create feelings in our bodies, hearts and minds for an end goal unto themselves

So what does graduating look like? It doesn’t mean forgetting how to mic a kit or tune a vocal. It doesn’t necessarily  mean minimalism. It doesn’t really mean anything except focussing on what matters; how the sounds make you and hopefully your audience feel. This is the basis of my repeated hope for people to “Listen like a 15 year old girl”. She doesn’t care about sound, she cares how it makes her *feel* 

An argument for feel is often viewed as an argument *against* great sound or *for* “phoning it in” which of course makes no sense. Many things can sound AND feel great, as long as you keep your eyes on the shadow on the wall, and not on your fingers….

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Growing up in Ireland, without PP I wouldn’t have known that making records could be a legitimate career.

It showcased real life *professionals* working at a high level, and was my introduction to the discourse around the industry. Having only experienced studio work as a cottage industry up to that point, PP opened my eyes to avenues I could pursue that I wouldn’t have known even existed otherwise (recording engineer is different to mixing engineer is different to producer is different to songwriter??!). It all seems very rudimentary now, but I was starting from literally nothing in a place with few (if any?) visible role models.

I learned so much from it on a technical level - from basic stuff like what a Pultec is and how people use it (connecting the dots between my cracked Waves bundle - Puigtec and who tf JJP was), what “a vocal chain” might look like and the purpose of each stage…

True, the interviews did become unbearable, but there was a golden era between eps around 30-90 at a time when outside of working in the studio world, there weren’t many other sources of good information from people who were really doing it.

Huge appreciation for Dave, and I hope he and his family get the support they need.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I dreamt last night that Eric Valentine turned out to be a hacky, big on YouTube but where are his credits type character. 

He'd leveraged the LWMR discord to sell 1,200 tickets to a 1 day masterclass type event, and had drawn all these people out to a field where he'd set up a huge marquee but no PA.

When the session started, he had a projector showing his screen but it was too small, and nobody could hear what he was talking about, or what he was playing back from his laptop speakers. At the lunch break, a single intern was serving unidentifiable yellowish slop to a huge queue of people on cheap paper plates. The people in the queue were all disappointed but trying to remain positive.

In the queue, Eric walked past grinning, and when I asked how he was doing, he said "can you believe it? I'm making $200 an hour today!!". 

Given everything I'd heard from @cian riordan and @oaklandmatt, I really expected more of Eric.

author: cian riordan
content:
Rich Costey doing a Q&A on the gearspace forum right now and it's just amazing. On mixing the Rage Renegades album with Rick Rubin: 

"Rick called me up after I worked on Fiona Apple "When The Pawn..". I learned a lot from him, primarily how to work from instinct instead of intellect. He would often make mix suggestions which I thought were bad ideas but I would of course do them because it's what he wanted, and they worked. He really did listen like a teenager, it was always simply whether or not he was getting off on something. If he wasn't, he'd make very clear suggestions on how to make something better. Sometimes he'd just say the mix sucked and to start over (only once). Sometimes the recording itself had issues and he would just deal with what's there. I think that turned into a serious strength of his- working with what's in front of him. We still keep in touch from time to time"

author: Rob Domos
content:
Love the whole conversation above. 

One thing to consider with the whole “people hire me for my taste” thing is that it’s important to have not only a refined palate, but also a broad enough one to be collaborating. 

I’ve worked with extremely talented people who don’t have the breadth to apply their skills to something even slightly outside of their *exact* preference, and I perceive that as being to their detriment. 

If you want to be a professional chef and you make incredible arrabbiata but begrudgingly phone it in with alfredo, you’re going to have a pretty poor career telling Italian restaurants that you’re the right guy for arrabbiata and the wrong guy for alfredo. That’s niching down a little too hard a little too early.

I think it’s our job to find the essence within something and maximally bring that essence out. Often these “taste mismatch” issues come across to me as missing that essence within the thing you’re working on and trying to make it something that it essentially isn’t. ie. A wannabe Max Martin working with a wannabe mitski and the producer complaining that the artist’s suggestions are making the production hashy and the artist complaining that the producer’s production choices don’t convey enough emotion. 

It’s talking past each-other and not really collaborating. You aren’t learning to truly love what your partner loves, which IMO is frankly a big part of the job.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Ok I'm gonna go in depth about this because I think it's FASCINATING.

The top three songs have an overlapping core fanbase that is largely unrepresented (or maligned) in popular culture: the white working class.

But none of them are really straightforward "country." 

The first song is a viral hit that seemingly comes from an authentic Appalachian kid talking about class. Despite his very explicit statements about hating political division, it has of course been wildly politicized because everything on the internet is these days.

The second song is a white male country singer covering a black lesbian female's iconic song ALSO about class. Talk about intersectionality...

The third song is the longest running solo male #1 song on the Hot 100 from the biggest star in country music (and really one of the biggest stars in the world... just, again, not covered by the current fashion of mainstream culture). It's a kinda-country-but-kinda-just-pop song co-written by the biggest country writer in history (Ashley Gorley) as well as once-rapper-and-Dr-luke-protege J Kash.

The rest of the chart is interesting too. #4 is a four year old taylor swift song that has gained traction online from her current tour so the label started pushing it as a single. 

There are two Olivia Rodrigo songs, signaling a true new superstar.

There are two songs from the Barbie soundtrack. In a "dying" movie industry currently on strike, when is the last time two songs from a movie soundtrack have been in the top 10? I dunno.

And lastly, there's only 1 trap song. The majority of these songs are people playing real instruments and writing more "classic" singer-songwriter songs. Rap music is really having a lull after a decade of dominance.

author: cian riordan
content:
"Sorry about the late night duplicate file, I did this track after six other people because I'm rushing as a team player.   I delivered as promised up front as we are all in overtime now to make it great.  *CLIENT* is happy with your work and with mine and we are all working overtime together.   Apologies also, I know there were some annoying ticks in there with some of the revised files. Still not sure why this one session did that. 

Of course I don't listen to every single file, post rendering.   We render and send 500-1000 files a month with the revisions on the 200-300 monthly songs that I do.  Team players don't ask such things on CC.  I work usually 7 days a week for 40-50 people a month, and making them happy with great masters is job #1.  Perfectionism is not a part of that process.    Software makes mistake, and that's ok.    People make mistakes and that's ok.   Mixes and masters should never aim for perfect, they should aim to connect, aim for humanity.  

Perfection is not the goal here, it's musicality and teamwork.  I'm sorry your ears suffered that horrible popping, but please, be cool. "

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Ok gang, here’s something I’ve been pondering

Imagine 3 sliders that go from 0 to 10. Your goal is to set the sliders to maximize your wellbeing (in the broadest sense) and the wellbeing of those close to  you. The sliders are in effect zero sum, in that the closer you are to one end then less you have of the attribute on the other end. Let’s set the time horizon to 25 years and acknowledge the seemingly increasing pace of change in the world

Ok, the sliders …

**#1 Classics vs Cutting Edge**
On this slider 0 represents maximum knowledge in a classical sense - literature, math, mythology, fundamental accepted basics in Biology/Chemistry/Physics etc etc. 10 represents complete literacy in the cutting edge of culture, science and technology - from memes and Reddit culture to AI to synthetic biology and Blockchain etc etc 

**#2 Specialist vs Generalist**
Here 0 represents a very deep and specific knowledge of a chosen field (could be a doctor or a producer) vs 10 representing a modern Jack of all trades who knows a little bit about a lot of things 

**#3 Short Term vs Long Term**
On the slider 0 represents a disposition all about short term wins, fast plays that close out over a year vs 10 representing long investments in a given idea/field/belief system

It goes without saying that the zero sum aspect here is artificial, you can of course have some long term plays happening alongside some short term, but it’s just to get the juices flowing

No matter where you’re at in the “making a record” chain, it’s probably a good idea to watch the YouTube of Chad Smith on Drumeo (the Dua Lipa one is good, but the 30 Seconds to Mars one is MINDBLOWING)

author: cian riordan
content: In defense of Peter, he and I operate in a VERY different world of vocal production than Beckley (and even yourself) do – with different sonic expectations, priorities, and goals. Beckley was part of the gang that forged new ground in modern pop vocal production... he's built a big part of his career on it, so of course we should listen to his insight. But there is another facet of the music industry that shoots for different outcomes (in Peter & I's case, that's records that don't sell and that nobody listens to).

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I love this.

I worked with a young artist recently. I asked him if he'd done his vocal warm-ups before he came in to cut vocals. He said "oh I forgot to do them." I asked him if he does them every day and he said "oh sometimes I forget."

I said "do you think professional athletes forget to stretch and warm-up?"

I told him if he thinks of it like homework, he won't be successful. But if he wakes up every day and says "I am a singer, this is who I am, of course this is what I do every day," then he's got a shot.

Now, if this happens on the first mix of an entire album you're slated to work on... it might behoove the question of "should we proceed?". But I find these instances few and far between.

author: peterlabberton
content:
Yeah… this is just me sharing my opinion, not trying to shit on anyone else’s: I am thoroughly uninterested in spatial/atmos. I’ve been able to listen in a few really swanky/certified rooms, to tracks that other more atmos-inclined folks were really pumped about, and I just thought it was gimmicky and—to my taste!—kinda lame. Not for any technical reason (though I have issues there as well), I just don’t care if a shaker sounds like it’s behind me and to the left or I’m *fully* enveloped in a reverb or whatever.

If I have to wrap my head around it to stay relevant, I’m fairly confident I can give my self a crash course—and if someone asked me to do an atmos mix and paid for the studio, then sure! But short of that… 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: One thing I will never ever ever do In mastering is send options. Never! In mastering it always breeds doubt, and seems to leave people wondering if they chose  the right one. Of course there is a “choice” between V1 and V2, but I’ll never send two different levels or two different eqs at once. I’m always presenting the current V as the definitive “now we have it” version

author: masteredbyjack
content:
@spectrummasters 

No surprise Ross with an extremely thoughtful post and approach, and you always with a very thoughtful initial question.

Gonna keep this as short as possible since it’s late, and I guess I’d sorta like to ruffle a few feathers lovingly. 

But from the freelance/work for hire side that I’m on, and most of us here are, I have to say, most people out here doing the thing are getting paid their ACTUAL value. 

Yet everyone thinks they are worth more. Why? Who cares that we work hard? Not the market. We make art that is totally non-essential to how society operates…for most of the projects we touch there is almost no demand and they will make very little money. Of course this doesn’t mean they are not important, I deeply think they are, but we are talking financial value here.

We need to either provide people with an amazing experience (in many ways) that they find valuable or help them earn more money. Ideally both

If you are undeniable and continue helping people earn more, feel more, be more, create more…the money cannot help but follow. And the market will tell you your value whether you like it or not

I don’t say this with the experience that others do, I have a long long way to go. so know that and of course take into account my perspective. This is all from a very loving place!

There’s reps, of course, finding the proper gurus, of course, but for me, a lot of the solutions for my weaknesses are found in community. I’m not great at A but I know 3 people who are. I’m decent at B but have no interest in it, however I know 2 other people who love it *and* are great at it. 

So my self-perceived weaknesses  ultimately led me to one of my actual strengths- culture & community building.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Came across a stimulating quote recently that I thought was illuminating. The person said the following (paraphrasing):

> "The definition of a nerd is someone who thinks conversation is for peer-reviewing ideas. What do non-nerds think it's for? Negotiating alignment."

Simply based on the way I've framed this question, it's probably pretty clear that I belong to the "peer-reviewing ideas" school of thought (mostly). I love to throw stuff out there, even if I don't believe it. I want to stress test it.

I can certainly appreciate conversation as a tool for aligning people on a belief or course of action, but it's got me wondering about how many of us are playing completely different games when we're having a conversation, and what other games are there? Do y'all think differently?

author: BatMeckley
content:
Years ago, a buddy of mine was DESPERATE for John Field’s snare sample. And i tried to explain to him it was more about arrangement and how the instruments around the snare work. And he was like “yeah I GET IT, but can I have the snare”. And this was a guy with good ears that plays guitar for STADIUMS.

So I say of course, come on by and I’ll give you the sample. And he without prompting goes “I’ll give you all my samples for that one”. I assure him that’s unnecessary but he insists. He comes by my place, plugs his drive in, and the very first sample he gives me is the John Fields snare sample.

I can’t help but think people are chasing proficiency in the wrong areas.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
As a former (what I would call pretty high level) athlete, I actually think about this thing very intently with regards to working on records and draw from things from the past life. Mine is more focused on how I want to hear (or rather deeply understand how I'm hearing) every day as close to consistent as possible, given we are human of course.

My 2 cents (which of course is just my experience): 

Some sort of routine before you work. Mine is that I wake up almost exactly at the same time every day, will work out at similar times (if possible), literally eat the same thing basically every day before during the work day, coffee at similar times, have  the same routine when I sit down to start work. Not all of that is possible or useful for everyone, but I think we can all find something that would focus us in a way that's useful and ablet to be put into practice for us.

Truly I find it helps a lot. We are physical beings, how our systems and bodies interact can definitely matter, especially in our ability to be available to the music.

That said, sometimes things happen and you gotta go. You will be tired, stressed, whatever. You have to do excellent work under those conditions too, it might be the most important skill if we are being honest about making a career of this. So training specifically for when you feel rough is definitely something I personally find important.  Which is where physically training helps, it's a way to force yourself into (fake) adversity and train response

@Slow Hand I know you know all this, just my experience

author: Rollmottle
content: The point isn't to tamp anybody's curiosity, it's to keep young record makers from wasting time on things that don't actually matter to the art of making records. A young record maker's bottleneck isn't their DAW choice. The discourse out there would have you believe your DAW choice, your plugins, the guitar bridge material, etc. are why you're not good enough yetl. Jon's mixes are incredible because of who he is, not because of the DAW he uses or what he believes about them. The kind of clip MWTM chose to highlight here simply feeds into the conflation of tools with results and are doing the broader community a disservice by leaning into it.

author: masteredbyjack

Love this discussion. All great points — my gut says there is a distinction between the producer/engineer role here and the artist. The learn grammar, be able to adjust and deliver on a vision/etc all lend themselves to being amazing technically and doing the reps to have those skills. Very useful on the service side

But some artists just have it like that. It’s irrelevant, they just crush stuff and have a vision. Pure talent. And probably the rarest ones have both sides and are aware of it. Then you’re truly dangerous

Have seen this with some football guys I’ve played with — I was one of the ones who studied the game deeply and could improve. But other guys showed up on day one, knew absolutely nothing but could just ball. Their knowledge of the game didn’t even matter, they could just ball on instinct. Of course they worked hard, but there was a different level of talent there. And look at them now, cashing checks in the NFL

author: Slow Hand
content:
More and more I'm beginning to appreciate that there is a gap between people living their lives in meatspace and the perpetually online. There's an entire strata of online discourse that's completely invisible to a lot of people, and they're probably better off for it.

It's odd how disconnected we can be from each other when we don't share the same media spaces. 

Despite the shortcomings of the old media models there were unifying benefits when people were all tuned into a small number of media outlets. I don't expect that will ever come back, but I wonder if there's a way to reduce the complexity of the fractured niche narratives that people are tuned into.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Absolutely @Nomograph Mastering i’ve got some perspective on this as I teach production and engineering as a visiting lecturer. The worst lectures (when I started) were just dense information with very little active element for the students. They had the info presented to them so that was learning, right? Of course, that was the wrong approach, and the more i’ve just provided broad themes to the group - i.e. make the sounds in front of you “angry, happy, distant, close” or “we will record/mix/master an EP within the next few weeks” the better the sessions go, and the more inquistive the students are to uncover the “learning” as they are doing.  I find making a fool of myself (“entertainment”) helps with this as it’s a useful tool to disarm the groups and build rapport. The more you can encourage students to learn from each other, and share the learning - prompted by me, the better the outcome is for everyone.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Quite a bit.

My learning is less music-focused these days, but I budget a lot of time for self-development and continued study.

Sometimes it's  20 min a day in a technical book that I'm reading. I move slowly and make sure I understand before I move on. It may take two months to complete, but I'm steady with it and I do a little bit most days. It's common for me to transcribe notes from high-density talks that I want to learn from and revisit them often over the span of a week. I'm constantly printing out my notes and reading material so that they're easy to revisit throughout the week.

I'm currently taking a project management course through MIT, which has been great. It's uncommon for me to do formal schooling these days, but this is work related and a direct application to my future capabilities that we thought would be beneficial for the company.

When I buy a new plugin (rare) I set aside time to go through it and turn every knob and try each feature to see what it's capable of. Learning a tool on the spot is a good way to kill the creative flow, so I do the exploration up-front when possible.

Often I'll have ideas for novel ways to use a tool (layering distortion, for example) and I'll set aside two hours to explore it and see what I find.

That said, I think my day-to-day may be quite different from a lot of folks here. My eggs aren't all in the business and pressures of record production, and so I rarely find myself buried in such commitments. I tend to keep "normal" business hours these days and keep a hard separation between my commitments and my leisure.

In fact I'd say that I'm actively structuring my life so that I can retain my leisure and don't find myself overwhelmed with commitments. That's a whole other story, though.

author: sinaigimenez
content:
I got really sad when I saw this. It probably hits harder because my dad is around the same age and has Parkinson’s it's not the same but… 
 Dave always seemed like a genuinely good person, and I’m grateful for how he tried to spread knowledge.

I’m with Cian on the interview quality — a lot of them were just awkward (the Justin Meldal-Johnsen one is a perfect example), and the absolute worst part was Herb. In the end, his stupid ego kinda killed the show. It was really annoying how he kept interrupting all the time and talking way more than Dave or the guest, about random shit that had nothing to do with the conversation. Fucking terrible.

BUT I can’t forget that back in the day, Pensado’s Place was one of the very few places where you could actually see your mixing heroes talk about making records. Even when the interviews were pretty bad like 85% of the time, I still had great moments watching Eric Valentine, Tchad Blake, JMJ, Ken Andrews, etc… and I learned some useful stuff too.

I’m from a small village in Northwest Spain (BTW, I heard Pensado has family roots here), and I had zero access to any info about how real records were made. So when I discovered Pensado’s Place, it was huge for me. Big thanks to Dave!! And I wish him nothing but the best in this sad new chapter. Good people and love for this art will always win for me, no matter the flaws. ❤️

author: spectrummasters
content:
As a concept , I think “truth “ is a tricky thing to pin down . It can’t really exist without its relationship to time . Truth changes with time . Imho. 

That said , I fully believe music contains archetypes , sacred geometries and of course waves themselves ,…..that are essentially the cosmos breathing and manifesting . That maths , physics and music all relate to each other , that natures forms , in patterns like the golden ratio to be found in a fern , or an excellent arrangement of a song , that sound and light energy all share phenomena ….these things , the patterns , the scales , the ratios and then the ancestral mind and genetic memory , the ancient truths , instincts , symbolic folklore and intuitions ….as Blake called it …..our imaginations being the direct experience of nature itself ….

When someone taps into that and writes something that speaks from and aligns those realms …..

author: Adam Thein
content:
My main tip for using Live live is try and replace as many third party plugins as you possibly can with stock, freeze as much as you can, and most of the latency you experience is going to be coming from internal delay compensation vs I/O latency.  If you are able to optimize your sets as much as possible, you can probably get away with running everything without offloading DSP to a UAD system.  If you are already in that ecosystem by all means!

I built a live set similar to what you have going based off of Daniel Mintseris Lynda (now LinkedIn Learning) videos that were amazingly helpful.  Also in my case I made samplers whenever possible of 3rd party synths if the patch didn't have a ton of modulation internally.  But yeah bottom line is keep an eye on your total device latency on groups (hovering over a group will display the total delay compensation/latency calculation in the Status Bar).

If you have any other questions for me feel free to DM!

Edit: we used a rackmount X32 for in ears that also served double duty as the audio interface running 16 i/o at 48khz and were able to do it on a 2015 macbook with minimal latency

author: ALXCPH
content:
Yes. The same way you do anything in life you want to get good at. Spend a shit load of time doing that thing. There really are no hacks or work arounds if you want to actually get good. An easy free way to do it is just learn as many songs as you can. If you want to really be proficient in the musical language I would recommend learning stuff by ear. It takes a lot longer than looking up tutorials or sheet music. But I promise you will develop your ears infinitely more. Specially in the beginning. Music is a language. Every human being learns to speak and converse before they learn how to spell and know the rules of grammar. Learning theory will only let you put names to sounds so that you can convey musical ideas to their people. Contrary to what a lot of people think, there are no rules, but there are a lot of conventions and traditions, but they keep changing and have lots of exceptions. Learning a shit ton of songs on whatever instrument you choose, will teach you what those conventions are and how to use them. 

In the beginning it’s good to just learn every song you like as well as you can, because it will help keep you motivated as you like the music. Then after a while you will probably want to branch out and try stuff you’ve never listened to or enjoyed before just to challenge yourself. 

The most musical people I know, are the people who wouldn’t know what to do with a Caugmented#9 but can listen to a song once and play it nearly perfectly, because their ears and musical language is so developed from playing a fuck lot of music and not spending time reading about it or watching endless tutorials.

@austenballard  On a similar thread I try to frame those situations like this. There’s no point worrying about something because if you can’t change it why worry and if you can, change it so you don’t have too. A huge simplification but something I find helpful with dealing with tough times in a studio. 

You can get that weird moment in a session when something goes wrong  usually the best course of action is to be a positive and hopeful force for the band or artist to rely on. 

“Let’s get this sorted as quickly as possible and get back to work”
Deep down I don’t think anyone really thinks you’re responsible for what ever happened, they’re just looking for a solution. Except of course Trevor, Trevor knows you did it and he’s mad.

author: Deleted User
content:
From my experience of going to music school and taking a whole bunch of courses that are all over the place in terms of lane of focus- school can offer almost too much. It helps to take some time to digest the information, I had this issue when I was in college and had a chat with some of the graduates and they said it took them years after graduating to decompose information that was learned. If you have doubts on if you should continue it may be useful to take some time off and spend on doing what you wanted to do, continuing to connect with people, or even just take breaks altogether to take a breeze of fresh air, live in outside world. Being in school kind of made me live in a bubble and getting out of that was really precious to me. 

Degree is just a piece of paper but academic settings can widen horizons of what you can access on your own in the future without having to rely on someone to feed the knowledge/information. It was very chaotic when I took a whole bunch of unrelated courses in college but they all offered me wide insights on what I could dig deeper into in the future. Did I transform as much as others that focused on one lane (eg. engineering) - then I would say no but I created my own program to gain things that would take me more than a decade to have access to. I wasn’t able to retain everything but it unlocked the ways so I can go there when I need to. 

It always sucked having no time to work on my own stuff, but I saw it as a training period  of my life rather than practical period of life. 

My case is slightly different than yours because I went to college straight without having much real world experience. But TLDR; I think semester or a year off would give you what you need without aborting any of the options!

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Not an answer to your question, but reminded me of a dynamic that I observed in my time assisting at major London studios:

There was a noticeable number of US clients (artists + their entourages, certain producers, and especially writers - usually in pop or hip hop) who treated assistants like “the help” / waiting staff / taxi drivers / some menial worker they felt was beneath them. The first few times it happened, it was kind of shocking, and very off-putting.

Of course there are going to be bell ends from every country (and there were plenty of exceptions - I've had many incredible sessions with North American clients, and some gross sessions with UK clients too), but it happened enough to wonder whether maybe it's a cultural thing?

Does this hold water with you US folks’ experience? FWIW, I can’t imagine anyone in this Discord treating anyone like that, let alone their colleagues. And of course, my personal experience is probably weighted 80/20 UK/international.

author: ehutton21
content:
Piggy backing on a lot of the great thoughts in here and recalling my own musical education, I would say dividing the curriculum into a “listening” component and a “creating” component would be critical. In hindsight, it was incredibly formative for me that ear training practice and actual theoretical/sheet music knowledge always came alongside the practical element of sitting at keys and performing the pieces I was assigned that week.

I like the idea of breaking down modern pop structure, I like the idea of covering signal flow a lot. I think you can teach and test signal flow in theory while allowing someone to practice their recording technique by mimicking the song structure of their favorite pop song. I’m not proposing that as an actual coursework suggestion (I doubt most would be ready for that week one) but just as a thought for course organization

author: Deleted User
content:
This can be controversial, but to execute C no matter what artist says or wants to do and present it. That way they can at least have a tangible result to compare it with. Instead of explaining, it’s better to do it and show it.

My humble take: our job is not necessarily doing what we’re told. it is to take their vision, and take it to a place where they could say “wow- I didn’t know this is what I wanted but this is what I want now”. Which I think is the taste and perspective factor. 

It is case by case of course and some artists could come in with A to Z manual of what they want, which can be cool- or not. I personally find those boring, unless I really admire their vision and it just feel like an honor to be a part of it. I think being a yes man can be a quick way to become dispensable. But someone who is willing to serve by giving you some friction that can turn into some heat 🔥 can be someone they find trustworthy and interesting. It’s case by case dependent, some people need perfect aerodynamics to accelerate their vision, and I don’t think that’s necessarily being a yes man- but rather about just being the right fit for the project and being someone who is fully on board to do what they are asking. 

But I think more importantly- it’s okay to miss. If they don’t like it - then scrap it or give it another go. And it’s also fine if you end up not being the one for the project

author: Slow Hand
content:
Been watching this all day. Dann seems to have such good character about everything. It's inspiring to see him play with so much care and attention to feel.

I loved hearing him talk about Mutt Lange's approach and how patient Mutt was with every part. Making the players play again and again while waiting for the right confluence of feel to come together before moving on. There's so much care for the moment. That pace is antithetical to the way things are often done today. Understandably so.

Of course, Dann also expresses the feelings of doubt that anyone would go through in his position; wondering what it was about him that wasn't good enough for the take. So I think it's good that Mutt was up-front with the players about how they were going to approach it, which could allow the players to stop thinking about their abilities and sink into the right headspace for such a long endeavor as Mutt explored.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Sing for real, practice the part a lot. 

No matter how detailed you get in the recording, singing is always a moment to moment performance. So locking in exact timing for onset, releases, breaths, little runs which change your mouth shape, etc…  to do it convincingly is, like I said, nigh impossible. 

But one of the things to make it more or less believable is to have the mic in the same general place in the video as you do the recording. A close mic’s performance and a wide angle video is easier to disbelieve 

And of course in a music video nobody actually expects that kind of perfection so it’s more about the visual energy.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I can understand the trepidation here. Now that Canva own Affinity, it's not yet clear what their strategy is. My guess is that there are a few reasons for this play:

1. Affinity Studio is now a loss leader for Canva's other offerings, like their (just announced) supplemental AI tool set or their enterprise plans, which I suspect are a big portion of their income compared to their Affinity suite licenses.

2. It eats into Adobe's market share. Making a very competitive alternative to Adobe's flagship software and then offering it for free encourages adoption by users who are ready to jump ship from their Adobe subscriptions or who need software like this and are fine without Adobe's cutting-edge tools (like me).

There are some positive examples of high-level *free* software that is continues to thrive with no sign of being abandoned, or compromised. Like DaVinci Resolve or Reaper (which is effectively free). There are also some great examples of open source software getting a new lease on life by their steward companies. Namely Musescore and Audacity's recent revamps. 

Now Affinity isn't open source, but Musegroup have a large full-time development team that seem to be getting by just fine developing what is effectively free software. If they can do it, then Affinity likely can.

Here's hoping Canva have done the math right before setting out on this course.

author: ALXCPH
content:
at your level i wouldnt worry about singing teachers. What i would worry about is connecting your vocal chords to your ears and brain. technique and breathing isn't something to worry about just yet. A teacher/mentor can be great for guidance. But they can be expensive. A few lessons could def put you in a direction. I would start with ear training learning to hear melodies. Usually when people are unable to hit a note it has less to do with technique and more to do with their ability to decern pitch and notes. 

Starting out is always tough, but start by singing everyday, sing along to your favourite songs. also try and pull up a piano and press a key and then sing the note, then press another key and sing that note, this will teach you to actively target notes with your voice/ears. Learn to sing simple songs on your own without any backing tracks or music. Nursery rhymes are great, they are simple and a lot of people have them internalised. When you get some more confidance, try and have a static chord or note, and sing different notes on top of it and see how the different notes feel / sound and really internalise that.

author: ALXCPH
content: if you learn piano at the same time as learning to sing it could help you visualise some of what your are learning(if you are a visual learner) and youll still be training your ears and pitch understanding and musicality

author: cian riordan
content: Insight gives you A LOT of visual information that isn't really useful unless you know what you're looking for. I have two visual meters while I mix... a janky old Goldline RTA analyzer and a TC Electronics Clarity. The RTA is useful for quick visual cues of kick to snare balance, how subby something really is, or when I'm working out phase relationships between drum mics... I can quickly glance to help aid with decision making. It's not necessary for me to mix, but I've had it for 15 years and it helps me make certain technical decisions quicker. The Clarity is very useful for the loudness radar. I basically set a guide LUFS (in my case, I'm usually shooting for -9) and you get a great visual representation of where you're at over the course of the song. Its especially useful to avoid fader creep... where I might nail the dynamics and loudness in the earlier parts of the song, but might overlook the last chorus being significantly louder, and in some cases, more squashed than it needs to be. I'm also an LCR panning guy, and it has a 'balance-o-meter' feature that has a cool weighted algorithm for determining if your mix is leaning left or right.

author: Slow Hand

Yeah. These AI's are definitely *not* thinking and I think we'll hit the limit of what machine-learning tools are capable of talking about. They're good at mimicking existing things, but they don't do anything at all approximating cause and effect, self-reflection, or abstract thought. 

I get the impression that this model is fundamentally flawed and unable to be a true general intelligence. Which I'm happy about. Cause that would be a whole other can of worms to worry over.

content:
I'm still formulating my thoughts, but my initial impression was that it felt more lifeless than I expected. Watching it spit out words one by one, felt like I was having a conversation with a dial up modem. Really, it felt like a more intuitive search engine, and less like it was feeding me anything I couldn't attain in other ways (through more effort).

I asked it some questions about where to find information about programming languages and it turned up some helpful resources. I spent awhile asking it to code some things for me and it did so impressively, while leaving bits in the code that explained what it was doing. I can see that being massively useful for bug-hunting, but also as a learning tool. I was fascinated when I asked it to code me a GUI for this fake program and it complied. But when I asked it to show me what that would actually look like, it linked to an IMGUR image that didn't exist.

If I walked away with one feeling, it was curiosity, instead of anything negative.

author: spectrummasters
content: Any other electricians in here? ive been discussing at work about harmonics in electrical circuits (caused by inductive loads usually) and how these are bad in electrical circuits.....but have become fascinated by the fact that harmonics in electrical circuits behave / form just as those in music (doubles of the fundamental frequency) . We obviously use transformers in electrical science and in analogue music and we talk about phase shift in both electrical science and audio engineering. I was speaking with my firm's supervisor about all this and the common terminology and he was pointing out that as audio engineers we use all the same terms because of course, audio engineering was founded from electrical engineering . What im very curious about is that in analogue circuits we transform sound pressure levels into electrcial circuits and voltages....which then become affected by these electrcial phenomena ......that often create pleasing artefacts once reconverted back to sound waves at the speaker (via overloading voltages and transformers and valves )

author: Deleted User
content:
how our clients come up with money to pay us is important in order to stay sustainable. because we’re technically in a business of helping another business (artists or labels) make money. 

huge part of our values are tied to our ability to make them money. so of course it matters. 

And our ability to make them money isn’t directly parallel to how good we are at what we do. If they made money, it’s probably because everyone in the team nailed it. But if it’s not making money- that’s not because we sucked at our job. 

Which is why I started getting more involved in artist branding, I wish I could offer enough insights in building a fan base and marketing side of things. Because then I can really be more in control of the situation. 

but even then- there’s not enough money in the market. there’s a long and steep valley of despair between climbing from bottom to top. I do think if there was more money in the pool, the valley of despair wouldn’t be that bad. and in order to pull more money in, crowdfunding could be one of the ways. I wish I can come up with more solutions…

author: Deleted User
content:
Late to the discussion, but I do think the word ‘talent’ is reductive and oversimplification of one’s complex combinations of innate character/traits. A lot of little things coming together is what makes up the ‘innate talent’. Things that give certain people a head start on different crafts can probably be analyzed into different components. While “either you have it or you don’t” can lead to defeatist thinking, I believe seeing them as a make up of different components can really bring out individuals’ best self. 

we all have our fortes, but not everyone is able to break them down and integrate the different strengths to create synergy. And the “talented” individuals are the ones who has integrated the different strengths, whether it was through deliberate discoveries or something that was given to them circumstantially. I believe rephrasing ‘innate talent’ to something like ‘natural qualities/traits’ can lead to more freedom and more useful perspective than “I could never be like X” - because of course you can’t, you are not X. 

Which brings back to what you were saying about the value of  journey over the prize

author: Will Melones
content:
Shouldn’t they care to know? I’ve heard so many people in my family say they have no musical talent or they’re terrible at piano, but they’ve never practiced for 15 minutes. What’s the measurable difference between Yo-Yo Ma and your uncle?

My gut feeling is that most of talent comes down to commitment/focus (interest in the craft) and learning styles, and then culture and early exposure mold that into an affinity.

Some people will suck at an art form, put in the work, and then not suck anymore. Some will be born with a brain that’s wired to seeing shapes, and find it easy to visualize patterns on a guitar neck. Some will be auditory learners and may find it easier to learn to identify intervals by ear.

And then some people will grow up singing or playing in church, and those people get the cheat codes from a *very* young age while their brains are still spongey, learning things like their first language. Of course they weren’t born playing the organ, but it can look that way from the outside.

It seems both mystical and defeatist when people who don’t think they have talent talk about people who do—almost like an excuse. And maybe that’s intentional, and exactly the point you’re making.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Not sure where to put this so we’ll start here and maybe we can migrate it if it lands in any way

Had a great call last week with @Josh. We talked about a bunch of stuff but one of the themes we explored was the idea that one needs a “portfolio” of slick & great sounding work to get hired

Once you’ve decided that then it becomes the focus, and changes the way things feel and the way decisions about time, who you work with etc get made. Concepts like “I’ll suck it up and work for free but *then* I will have a singular “good track” for my portfolio”. Of course there are exceptions but it feels to me that there’s something very constricting and materialist about this way of being in the world. There can be a tension between what the artist wants or what the song wants to be and what makes you look “good” in your portfolio - they want mono and grimy but you want wide/lush/impressive

In our jam I proposed a kind of thought experiment, an end of the line or extreme of the “need portfolio” way of thinking…

So let’s say you are here, a young writer, producer, mixer. You’ve been doing it 3 or 4 years. You feel that one of the reasons you are not getting hired, getting shots or getting paid well is that there isn’t a body of work for a potential client to judge you by. Ok, here’s comes the magic trick. I’m going to grant you a genie wish portfolio! 5 killer tracks with  great collaborators. Not hot 100 #1 but the kind of work that you really feel would represent you best in the world. Boom. There it is…

So now what? You get some DMs and sessions start happening. But you’re not ready. You’re not fit for game day. You’re in over your head, and don’t have the fluency, the experience, the reps and the humblings that build a great music business pro. In short you’re not ready for the opportunities the genie wish portfolio granted you

author: masteredbyjack
content:
responding to @SoundsLikeJoe  as well -- 

This exactly. I want to solve problems. Of course if there is something that is very noticeable that can't be resolved convincingly, I will absolutely flag it. Truly, I want the art to be the best it can and almost every single person I've worked with agrees.

BUT -- why wouldn't you just want me to remove a click, attenuate an s, etc? Even did one today where I was removing some high end on just a few clap hits, easy in RX.  Attenuating down the volume of a breath, whatever. Easy. Almost always the result is indistinguishable from you removing it on your end. Then you don't have to reprint, etc etc, the artist gets it faster, everyone wins.

Then there is also the issue of where the click or artifact is actually coming from. Lead vocal? Backgrounds? One of 15 of the background stacks? So much easier for me to just zap the issue on my end from the stereo file. Again, with all this being that the result is equal (and oftentimes better I'd argue)

Obviously if the edit is in the way of connection to the song or it genuinely would sound better as an edit in the mix, we do that. But even something like bridging a bad edit that has a space in an s, etc can be done well with spectral repair replace!

author: Zakhiggins
content:
I was recently inspired after going to the cinema to see *A Complete Unkown*, the movie memoir about Bob Dylan; partially by Bob's story, but also by Timothy Chalomee's performance as Bob. All of the shots of him performing in the movie were fully live - which is an impressive feat by itself - but even more impressive that he apparently wasn't much of a musician before making the movie. I didnt know much about Timothy before this, so I watched his interview with Zane Lowe on Apple Music's YouTube channel. One thing I found really interesting was how available he made himself to learning the role. For example, he didn't turn his phone on for 3 months straight. Got me thinking about how much I can get distracted during the day, and how these distractions can get in the way of me actually giving 100% to the art that I'm working on. I'm sure you all can imagine how the distractions in your own life can effect your work. Might be TikTok videos, might be discord, might be lusting over getting new converters or monitors or guitars, etc, you get the idea. So I guess what I'm saying here is that if I want to compete with the best, maybe I have to understand how to impliment systems in my life that allows me to be more available to the things that I am working on. I want it to be like lifiting a heavy weight at the gym - at the bottom of a heavy squat, you've no choice but to focus on pushing the bar back up with good form, cos that think will break you otherwise. There's a certain thing that happens in your brain when you're forced to only think about one thing for a prolonged, or even short period. It's something akin to meditating. 

I guess what I'm asking is if anyone has ever given this subject any thought before, and if anyone has ever done anything to get better at these things? I'm still not sure if all this only makes sense inside my own head.

author: Deleted User
content:
Thank you all for chiming in on this, it really got me thinking! I took some time to dig deeper into my uncomfort with this topic and I think it’s really just about the concept of a “personality trait”. Maybe we can jam a little on it.

I had this example in mind:
Let’s say we meet someone for the first time and while we’re interacting I gather that this person seems like a “happy person”, they’re smiling, giving off warm vibes and are kind. We keep on meeting this person and the experience repeats itself. So the more we meet, the more our idea that this person must be a “happy person” solidifies. We know of course that this is an abstraction and that the person is probably going to be sad, angry, etc. at times. 

Now let’s say we think, man I really liked this person they are so easy to deal with, I enjoyed every bit of our interaction. I wish more people would be like that! And there you go. Now you are set to figure out all the details about happiness, the factors that make a “happy person” a “happy person”. The warmness, the kindness etc. and help people be more happy. 

Now you’re really digging into it, you start making videos, writing blogs going out to teach happiness. People are really digging it and you feel like you’re doing good for the world. So the concept is in everyone’s mind happiness is what we should strive for and whoever is not happy enough yet just needs to try harder. Suddenly you’re watching the news and you hear more and more people are getting symptoms of depression, stress and anxiety. And you think to yourself wow how did that happen? I thought I was making   the world a better place. 

And I think that’s what’s happening with a lot of these concepts that once they get institutionalized or gain popularity they somewhat lose their initial intent and can even have a rebounding effect. I mean we can see it going that way with a lot of different trends like mindfulness, health awareness, the work life balance etc.

author: Deleted User

What I’m rather trying to think about is if there’s a way to discuss all of this without the construction of norms that bog down on people.
